Author: thirdeyevalhalla

Comment: It's looking increasingly likely that the EU and China have both concluded that Trump isn't a threat, but an opportunity. If the EU and China can work out how to co-operate, they can carve up global trade between them. Pull in Canada, Mexico, Japan, Australia, New Zealand and Latin America, and you've got a full world of trade, except for the US. This is a chance for everyone else to cut the US out of the world economy and replace it with a duopoly; the US can just wither on the vine. It may take a couple of decades, but this could be the beginning of the end for the US as a first-tier economic power.

Comment: The EU/US relationship is far more valuable overall than the EU/China relationship, so under normal circumstances, the decision would’ve been easy. In an economic fight between the US and China, the EU would generally lean toward giving the US preferential treatment.  The EU runs a €198.2 billion trade surplus with the US (as of 2024), compared to a €304.5 billion deficit with China. Historically, the US-EU trade relationship has fueled growth on both sides, helping the EU economy flourish.  But there's a slight problem: the EU needs trade with China... and for the same reason we need it: there's no quick or easy replacement for the supply chains that come from China. Stuff like components, materials, consumer goods - things you cannot easily replace locally.  ...And when US policy turns erratic or outright adversarial, that dependence becomes non-negotiable.  Worse yet, the EU's strong trade surplus with the US is now effectively a wildcard. All it takes is one bad day and the whims of the guy at the helm and tariffs are back. They could cut off China, make a show of loyalty, and then get burned anyway because Mr. Sundowning was in a bad mood because of something "AlphaMale42069" said on Twitter about how "weak" he was.  What I see happening: they'll do what they can to appease the US just enough to buy time while building trade bridges elsewhere... likely with the same countries the US has alienated.
